answers.text: Robert Koch and Emil von Behring

qas.question: According to the humoral theory of immunity, what were the bodies immune agents?
What was suggested in immunology before the 19th century?

plausible_answers.text: Robert Koch and Emil von Behring

qas.question: Who were the main detractors of the humoral theory of immunity?
What did cellular theory claim was in an organism's humors?

context: Immunology is strongly experimental in everyday practice but is also characterized by an ongoing theoretical attitude. Many <b5_0>theories<b5_0/> have been suggested in immunology from the end of the nineteenth century up to the present time. The end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century saw a battle between <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>"cellular" and "humoral"<a0_1/> theories<a0_2/> of immunity<a0_0/>. According to the cellular theory of immunity, represented in particular by <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b6_0>Elie Metchnikoff<b6_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>, it was cells – more precisely, <a2_0><a2_1><a2_2>phagocytes<a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/> – that were responsible for immune responses. In contrast, the humoral theory of immunity, held, among others, by <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><b7_0>Robert Koch and Emil von Behring<b7_0/><a3_1/><a3_0/>,<a3_2/> stated that the <b8_0>active immune agents<b8_0/> were <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>soluble components<a4_1/> (molecules)<a4_2/><a4_0/> found in the organism’s “humors” rather than its cells.
